head.title: Yet Another Argument for Nap Rooms in the Workplace

hedline.hl1: Yet Another Argument for Nap Rooms in the Workplace

abstract.p: Poll by online recruiter CareerEngine finds workers believe they do best 'brainstorming' about jobs when they are not actually working but in place of relaxation like bed or shower stall; drawing (S)

block.p: Here is a nugget you might want to pass on to your boss: A new survey shows that workers believe they do their best brainstorming about their jobs when they are not actually working.
In fact, to hear the respondents tell it, the ideal breeding ground for ideas is a place of relaxation far from the office, like a bed or a shower stall.

In fact, to hear the respondents tell it, the ideal breeding ground for ideas is a place of relaxation far from the office, like a bed or a shower stall.

The poll, by the online recruiter CareerEngine, also showed a high level of job dissatisfaction among respondents -- and an equally common perception that their bosses were unware of it. Little wonder, says John Remington, a professor at the Carlson School of Management at the University of Minnesota.
Companies merge and downsize and employees are left with broader job descriptions and less super-vision, he said.
